member.summary: Low-level access to the designed component's window procedure.
member.param: The windows message that was passed to our designed component's window procedure.

remarks.para: This function is used to handle all mouse-related input that occurs over the 's internal . We want the design-time behavior to mimick the run-time behavior as closely as possible, but we also want special functionality (like drag-and-drop rearrangement) during design-time.

In order to get this behavior, manual intervention is required when it comes to processing mouse messages for the 's . This code must intercept all mouse-related messages that are destined for this TreeView and force the expected behavior.

member.name: T:WRM.Windows.Forms.PaneNode
member.summary: PaneNode contains all information necessary to uniquely identify a conceptual node in a .

remarks.para: Because of s, s do not necessarily contain all the information necessary to identify themselves uniquely in the . This is simply because there is a 1-to-N relationship between an instance of a and nodes in the .

A PaneNode represents a single conceptual node in the . A PaneNode may or may not represent a descendant - it doesn't matter. The PaneNode keeps all of the information like , , etc... so that the various descendants of and don't have to keep up with these things.

In addition to these duties, a PaneNode also keeps track of all its child PaneNodes via its property. Any PaneNode objects that are members of this collection will appear as children of this PaneNode in the .

member.name: T:WRM.Windows.Forms.UserPropertyPane
member.summary: A custom version of PropertyPane that should be used as the base class for all customized versions of PropertyPane.

remarks.para: This class exists soley to force all classes that descend from it to be associated with the regular ControlDesigner instead of the PropertyPaneDesigner. This action is necessary because user defined types of PropertyPanes should not act as parent controls during design-time.

This reapplication of the Designer attribute does not affect the relationship with PropertyPaneRootDesigner. This root designer will always be used to host the design view of any user defined PropertyPane derivative.
